Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Modeling DNA Manufacturing Processes Using Extensible Attribute Grammars

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project supports the NSF mission of advancing the national health, prosperity and welfare by increasing the capabilities, accessibility and affordability of manufacturing services in support of America's leadership in the life sciences. The execution of many complex DNA manufacturing projects essential for life sciences research requires the combination of existing DNA fragments derived from biological samples with new DNA fragments chemically synthesized by commercial operators. Most life science laboratories lack the essential computational resources needed to plan and execute the complex manufacturing workflows required on their own, while commercial services are unwilling to perform the expensive, small batch and highly customized syntheses that are needed. As a result, the demands of many life science laboratories are outrunning the current capabilities of commercial operators. This project will explore the potential for creating a cybermanufacturing system that can make custom DNA fabrication accessible to end-users. Advances from the research will ultimately be incorporated into highly advanced commercial operations to serve the needs of the nation's life sciences research community.

The project creatively presents DNA manufacturing as a compelling domain for developing the conceptual framework needed to enable cybermanufacturing. The project will model DNA manufacturing processes using extensible attribute grammars that capture the relationships between the structure and performance of synthesis processes. The power of this conceptual breakthrough will be demonstrated by specifying a domain-specific programming language that will allow end-users to define, analyze, and execute complex DNA manufacturing projects. The language will initially accommodate three classes of projects that represent a broad range of DNA synthesis needs: 1) insertion of a synthetic DNA fragment into an existing plasmid, 2) producing a library of plasmids that represents the combinatorial assembly of a given set of DNA building blocks and 3) editing the genome of yeast strains; an example of whole genome engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since 2000, a number of companies have provided DNA synthesis services on a fee for service basis. The cost of DNA synthesis services has steadily decreased while the industry capacity has increased. Despite this rapid progress, the dream of systematically outsourcing DNA fabrication to DNA foundries remains elusive. Many DNA fabrication projects are beyond the capabilities of commercial service providers whose business models focus on providing generic standardized services at a low cost to a large number of users.

 

The rapid evolution of the DNA synthesis marketplace is confusing to end-users. Capabilities and prices are evolving so rapidly that many potential users of DNA synthesis rely on outdated assumptions to make manufacturing decisions. The proliferation of specialized vendors forces users to take responsibility for their DNA manufacturing projects. Unfortunately, potential users of synthetic DNA lack the computational resources needed to plan and execute complex manufacturing processes that involve specialized service providers and operations performed in their own laboratory. 

 

In order to empower life scientists to make the most of DNA synthesis technologies, we proposed to develop a custom programming language to specify DNA manufacturing processes. By taking advantage of recent developments in language engineering, it will be possible to extend the language to reflect the latest developments in DNA synthesis technologies.  This approach will enable users to compare different manufacturing strategies and find the optimal manufacturing strategy.

 

Intellectual Merits

This project was positioned at the interface between manufacturing, life sciences, and computer science. It took advantage of recent developments in computer language engineering and DNA synthesis technologies to develop a generic framework supporting a user-centric approach to DNA manufacturing. Instead of supporting rigid manufacturing processes managed by service providers, it empowers end-users to design and control distributed manufacturing processes that take advantage of the rapid evolution of the marketplace along with the user’s internal capabilities.  

 

The project uncovered unique manufacturing challenges faced in biomanufacturing. In most industries, people can design process from experience or from first principles with a high-level of confidence that the process will produce what it has been designed to manufacture. In life sciences this is not the case. The vast majority of biomanufacturing processes require an empirical development effort because it is simply not possible to get a working process without extensive trials and errors. 

 

In addition, many biomanufacturing processes have a very high rate of systematic failure. Some manufacturing steps fail to assemble specific objects for reasons that are not known in advance. For example, some DNA sequences have uncharacterized features that make them incompatible with specific assembly technologies. As a result, DNA manufacturing and other biomanufacturing processes tend to be very complicated because they need to anticipate systematic failure and include alternative manufacturing strategies.

Lack of predictive models and systematic failure are major obstacle to automation because they greatly increase the cost of automating a process to the point that it is often not cost-effective. In this context, it is strategic to find ways of reducing the cost of automating biomanufacturing processes using approaches like the ones that were the focus of this project.

 

Our original vision was to represent manufacturing processes as programs written in a custom programing language. However, we now suspect that it may be more effective to develop a custom language to represent a grid of manufacturing services rather than the process. This change of perspective makes it possible to think of a manufacturing process as a path on manufacturing grid. Many routing algorithms are available to find the optimal process by navigating this grid. 

 

Broader Impacts

This project provided training opportunities to four students enrolled in undergraduate and graduate programs in computer science, engineering, and life science. 

 

We developed a standardized training program allowing us to rapidly qualify students with no prior experience. This training program is focused on the acquisition of technical skills not academic knowledge. It makes it possible to minimize the cost of training factory workers and could potentially be applied in industry. The program was well received by the students. They liked the self-paced training. They preferred being in charge of their own training better compared to a more traditional training relying on shadowing more experienced scientists. This training program was developed using the laboratory information management system. We are looking for ways of making this accessible to people outside our organization.

 

The project has supported a number of other research projects in life sciences by bringing a manufacturing perspective that helped achieve the project scientific objectives. In particular, several people involved in this project were also involved in a project to develop a collection of 6,500 yeast mutants. The project catalyzed the development of a research center composed of faculty interested in developing manufacturing methods to support high-throughput experimental workflows in life science.
